member.returns: True if the actor is intersected by the ray, otherwise false.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.BrushSurface.Intersects(FlaxEngine.Ray@,System.Single@,FlaxEngine.Vector3@)
member.summary: Determines if there is an intersection between the brush surface and a ray. If collision data is available on the CPU performs exact intersection check with the geometry. Otherwise performs simple vs test. For more efficient collisions detection and ray casting use physics.
member.param: When the method completes and returns true, contains the distance of the intersection (if any valid).
When the method completes, contains the intersection surface normal vector (if any valid).
member.returns: True if the actor is intersected by the ray, otherwise false.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.GamepadVibrationState
member.summary: General identifiers for potential force feedback channels. These will be mapped according to the platform specific implementation.
member.remarks: For example, the PS4 only listens to the `large` channels and ignores the rest, while the Xbox One could map the `large` to the handle motors and `small` to the trigger motors. And iOS can map `LeftSmall` to its single motor.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.LimitLinearRange
member.summary: Represents a joint limit between two distance values. Lower value must be less than the upper value.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.LimitLinearRange.ContactDist
member.summary: Distance from the limit at which it becomes active. Allows the solver to activate earlier than the limit is reached to avoid breaking the limit.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.LimitLinearRange.Restitution
member.summary: Controls how do objects react when the limit is reached, values closer to zero specify non-elastic collision, while those closer to one specify more elastic (i.e bouncy) collision. Must be in [0, 1] range.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.LimitLinearRange.Spring
member.summary: The spring that controls how are the bodies pulled back towards the limit when they breach it.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.LimitLinearRange.Lower
member.summary: The lower distance of the limit. Must be less than upper.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.LimitLinearRange.Upper
member.summary: The upper distance of the limit. Must be more than lower.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.LimitLinearRange.Default
member.summary: The default structure with empty limit.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.LimitLinearRange.#ctor(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Constructs a hard limit. Once the limit is reached the movement of the attached bodies will come to a stop.
member.param: The lower distance of the limit. Must be less than upper.
The upper distance of the limit. Must be more than lower.
Distance from the limit at which it becomes active. Allows the solver to activate earlier than the limit is reached to avoid breaking the limit. Specify -1 for the default.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.LimitLinearRange.#ctor(System.Single,System.Single,FlaxEngine.SpringParameters,System.Single)
member.summary: Constructs a soft limit. Once the limit is reached the bodies will bounce back according to the restitution parameter and will be pulled back towards the limit by the provided spring.
member.param: The lower distance of the limit. Must be less than upper.
The upper distance of the limit. Must be more than lower.
The spring that controls how are the bodies pulled back towards the limit when they breach it.

Controls how do objects react when the limit is reached, values closer to zero specify non-elastic collision, while those closer to one specify more elastic (i.e bouncy) collision. Must be in [0, 1] range.

member.summary: Represents a joint limit that constraints movement to within an elliptical cone.

member.summary: Distance from the limit at which it becomes active. Allows the solver to activate earlier than the limit is reached to avoid breaking the limit.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.LimitConeRange.Restitution
member.summary: Controls how do objects react when the limit is reached, values closer to zero specify non-elastic collision, while those closer to one specify more elastic (i.e bouncy) collision. Must be in [0, 1] range.

member.summary: The spring that controls how are the bodies pulled back towards the limit when they breach it.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.LimitConeRange.YLimitAngle
member.summary: The Y angle of the cone (in degrees). Movement is constrained between 0 and this angle on the Y axis.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.LimitConeRange.ZLimitAngle
member.summary: The Z angle of the cone (in degrees). Movement is constrained between 0 and this angle on the Z axis.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.LimitConeRange.Default
member.summary: The default structure with a 45 degree cone limit.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.LimitConeRange.#ctor(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Constructs a hard limit. Once the limit is reached the movement of the attached bodies will come to a stop.
member.param: The Y angle of the cone (in degrees). Movement is constrained between 0 and this angle on the Y axis.
The Z angle of the cone (in degrees). Movement is constrained between 0 and this angle on the Z axis.
Distance from the limit at which it becomes active. Allows the solver to activate earlier than the limit is reached to avoid breaking the limit. Specify -1 for the default.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.LimitConeRange.#ctor(System.Single,System.Single,FlaxEngine.SpringParameters,System.Single)

The Z angle of the cone (in degrees). Movement is constrained between 0 and this angle on the Z axis.
The spring that controls how are the bodies pulled back towards the limit when they breach it.

Controls how do objects react when the limit is reached, values closer to zero specify non-elastic collision, while those closer to one specify more elastic (i.e bouncy) collision. Must be in [0, 1] range.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Mesh.UpdateMesh(FlaxEngine.Vector3[],System.Int32[],FlaxEngine.Vector3[],FlaxEngine.Vector3[],FlaxEngine.Vector2[],FlaxEngine.Color32[])
member.summary: Updates the model mesh vertex and index buffer data. Can be used only for virtual assets (see and ). Mesh data will be cached and uploaded to the GPU with a delay.
member.param: The mesh vertices positions. Cannot be null.
The mesh index buffer (triangles). Uses 32-bit stride buffer. Cannot be null.
The normal vectors (per vertex). Use null to compute them from normal vectors.

member.param: The mesh vertices positions. Cannot be null.
The mesh index buffer (triangles). Uses 16-bit stride buffer. Cannot be null.
The tangent vectors (per vertex). Use null to compute them from normal vectors.

member.summary: Updates the model mesh index buffer data. Can be used only for virtual assets (see and ). Mesh data will be cached and uploaded to the GPU with a delay.
member.param: The mesh index buffer (triangles). Uses 32-bit stride buffer. Cannot be null.

member.summary: Updates the model mesh index buffer data. Can be used only for virtual assets (see and ). Mesh data will be cached and uploaded to the GPU with a delay.
member.param: The mesh index buffer (triangles). Uses 16-bit stride buffer. Cannot be null.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Mesh.DownloadVertexBuffer0(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Downloads the first vertex buffer that contains mesh vertices data. To download data from GPU set to true and call this method from the thread other than main thread (see ).
member.param: If set to true the data will be downloaded from the GPU, otherwise it can be loaded from the drive (source asset file) or from memory (if cached). Downloading mesh from GPU requires this call to be made from the other thread than main thread. Virtual assets are always downloaded from GPU memory due to lack of dedicated storage container for the asset data.
member.returns: The gathered data.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Mesh.DownloadVertexBuffer1(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Downloads the second vertex buffer that contains mesh vertices data. To download data from GPU set to true and call this method from the thread other than main thread (see ).
member.param: If set to true the data will be downloaded from the GPU, otherwise it can be loaded from the drive (source asset file) or from memory (if cached). Downloading mesh from GPU requires this call to be made from the other thread than main thread. Virtual assets are always downloaded from GPU memory due to lack of dedicated storage container for the asset data.
member.returns: The gathered data.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Mesh.DownloadVertexBuffer2(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Downloads the third vertex buffer that contains mesh vertices data. To download data from GPU set to true and call this method from the thread other than main thread (see ).
member.remarks: If mesh has no vertex colors (stored in vertex buffer 2) the the returned value is null.
member.param: If set to true the data will be downloaded from the GPU, otherwise it can be loaded from the drive (source asset file) or from memory (if cached). Downloading mesh from GPU requires this call to be made from the other thread than main thread. Virtual assets are always downloaded from GPU memory due to lack of dedicated storage container for the asset data.
member.returns: The gathered data or null if mesh has no vertex colors.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Mesh.DownloadVertexBuffer(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Downloads the raw vertex buffer that contains mesh vertices data. To download data from GPU set to true and call this method from the thread other than main thread (see ).
member.param: If set to true the data will be downloaded from the GPU, otherwise it can be loaded from the drive (source asset file) or from memory (if cached). Downloading mesh from GPU requires this call to be made from the other thread than main thread. Virtual assets are always downloaded from GPU memory due to lack of dedicated storage container for the asset data.
member.returns: The gathered data.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Mesh.DownloadIndexBuffer(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Downloads the index buffer that contains mesh triangles data. To download data from GPU set to true and call this method from the thread other than main thread (see ).
member.remarks: If mesh index buffer format (see ) is then it's faster to call .
member.param: If set to true the data will be downloaded from the GPU, otherwise it can be loaded from the drive (source asset file) or from memory (if cached). Downloading mesh from GPU requires this call to be made from the other thread than main thread. Virtual assets are always downloaded from GPU memory due to lack of dedicated storage container for the asset data.
member.returns: The gathered data.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Mesh.DownloadIndexBufferUShort(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Downloads the index buffer that contains mesh triangles data. To download data from GPU set to true and call this method from the thread other than main thread (see ).
member.remarks: If mesh index buffer format (see ) is then data won't be downloaded.
member.param: If set to true the data will be downloaded from the GPU, otherwise it can be loaded from the drive (source asset file) or from memory (if cached). Downloading mesh from GPU requires this call to be made from the other thread than main thread. Virtual assets are always downloaded from GPU memory due to lack of dedicated storage container for the asset data.
member.returns: The gathered data.

member.returns: The created virtual material instance.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.ModelEntryInfo.Intersects(FlaxEngine.Ray,System.Single@)
member.summary: Determines if there is an intersection between the model actor mesh entry and a ray. If mesh data is available on the CPU performs exact intersection check with the geometry. Otherwise performs simple vs test. For more efficient collisions detection and ray casting use physics.
member.param: When the method completes and returns true, contains the distance of the intersection.
member.returns: True if the actor is intersected by the ray, otherwise false.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.ModelEntryInfo.Intersects(FlaxEngine.Ray,System.Single@,FlaxEngine.Vector3@)
member.summary: Determines if there is an intersection between the model actor mesh entry and a ray. If mesh data is available on the CPU performs exact intersection check with the geometry. Otherwise performs simple vs test. For more efficient collisions detection and ray casting use physics.
member.param: When the method completes and returns true, contains the distance of the intersection (if any valid).
When the method completes, contains the intersection surface normal vector (if any valid).
member.returns: True if the actor is intersected by the ray, otherwise false.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.SkinnedMesh.UpdateMesh(FlaxEngine.Vector3[],System.Int32[],FlaxEngine.Int4[],FlaxEngine.Vector4[],FlaxEngine.Vector3[],FlaxEngine.Vector3[],FlaxEngine.Vector2[])
member.summary: Updates the skinned model mesh vertex and index buffer data. Can be used only for virtual assets (see and ). Mesh data will be cached and uploaded to the GPU with a delay.
member.param: The mesh vertices positions. Cannot be null.
The mesh index buffer (triangles). Uses 32-bit stride buffer. Cannot be null.
The skinned mesh blend indices buffer. Contains indices of the skeleton bones (up to 4 bones per vertex) to use for vertex position blending. Cannot be null.
The skinned mesh blend weights buffer (normalized). Contains weights per blend bone (up to 4 bones per vertex) of the skeleton bones to mix for vertex position blending. Cannot be null.
The normal vectors (per vertex). Use null to compute them from normal vectors.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.SkinnedMesh.UpdateMesh(FlaxEngine.Vector3[],System.UInt16[],FlaxEngine.Int4[],FlaxEngine.Vector4[],FlaxEngine.Vector3[],FlaxEngine.Vector3[],FlaxEngine.Vector2[])
member.summary: Updates the skinned model mesh vertex and index buffer data. Can be used only for virtual assets (see and ). Mesh data will be cached and uploaded to the GPU with a delay.
member.param: The mesh vertices positions. Cannot be null.
The mesh index buffer (triangles). Uses 16-bit stride buffer. Cannot be null.
The skinned mesh blend indices buffer. Contains indices of the skeleton bones (up to 4 bones per vertex) to use for vertex position blending. Cannot be null.
The skinned mesh blend weights buffer (normalized). Contains weights per blend bone (up to 4 bones per vertex) of the skeleton bones to mix for vertex position blending. Cannot be null.
The tangent vectors (per vertex). Use null to compute them from normal vectors.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.SkinnedMesh.DownloadVertexBuffer0(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Downloads the first vertex buffer that contains mesh vertices data. To download data from GPU set to true and call this method from the thread other than main thread (see ).
member.param: If set to true the data will be downloaded from the GPU, otherwise it can be loaded from the drive (source asset file) or from memory (if cached). Downloading mesh from GPU requires this call to be made from the other thread than main thread. Virtual assets are always downloaded from GPU memory due to lack of dedicated storage container for the asset data.
member.returns: The gathered data.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.SkinnedMesh.DownloadVertexBuffer(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Downloads the raw vertex buffer that contains mesh vertices data. To download data from GPU set to true and call this method from the thread other than main thread (see ).
member.param: If set to true the data will be downloaded from the GPU, otherwise it can be loaded from the drive (source asset file) or from memory (if cached). Downloading mesh from GPU requires this call to be made from the other thread than main thread. Virtual assets are always downloaded from GPU memory due to lack of dedicated storage container for the asset data.
member.returns: The gathered data.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.SkinnedMesh.DownloadIndexBuffer(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Downloads the index buffer that contains mesh triangles data. To download data from GPU set to true and call this method from the thread other than main thread (see ).
member.remarks: If mesh index buffer format (see ) is then it's faster to call .
member.param: If set to true the data will be downloaded from the GPU, otherwise it can be loaded from the drive (source asset file) or from memory (if cached). Downloading mesh from GPU requires this call to be made from the other thread than main thread. Virtual assets are always downloaded from GPU memory due to lack of dedicated storage container for the asset data.
member.returns: The gathered data.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.SkinnedMesh.DownloadIndexBufferUShort(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Downloads the index buffer that contains mesh triangles data. To download data from GPU set to true and call this method from the thread other than main thread (see ).
member.remarks: If mesh index buffer format (see ) is then data won't be downloaded.
member.param: If set to true the data will be downloaded from the GPU, otherwise it can be loaded from the drive (source asset file) or from memory (if cached). Downloading mesh from GPU requires this call to be made from the other thread than main thread. Virtual assets are always downloaded from GPU memory due to lack of dedicated storage container for the asset data.
member.returns: The gathered data.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.SpringParameters
member.summary: Controls spring parameters for a physics joint limits. If a limit is soft (body bounces back due to restitution when the limit is reached) the spring will pull the body back towards the limit using the specified parameters.

member.summary: The spring strength. Force proportional to the position error.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.SpringParameters.Damping
member.summary: Damping strength. Force proportional to the velocity error.

member.summary: The default structure.

member.summary: Constructs a spring.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.ForceMode
member.summary: Force mode type determines the exact operation that is carried out when applying the force on a rigidbody.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.ForceMode.Force
member.summary: Add a continuous force to the rigidbody, using its mass. The parameter has unit of mass * distance / time^2, i.e. a force.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.ForceMode.Impulse
member.summary: Add an instant force impulse to the rigidbody, using its mass. The parameter has unit of mass * distance / time.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.ForceMode.VelocityChange
member.summary: Add an instant velocity change to the rigidbody, ignoring its mass. The parameter has unit of distance / time, i.e. the effect is mass independent: a velocity change.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.ForceMode.Acceleration
member.summary: Add a continuous acceleration to the rigidbody, ignoring its mass. The parameter has unit of distance / time^2, i.e. an acceleration. It gets treated just like a force except the mass is not divided out before integration.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.PhysicsCombineMode
member.summary: Enumeration that determines the way in which two material properties will be combined to yield a friction or restitution coefficient for a collision.
member.remarks: Physics doesn't have any inherent combinations because the coefficients are determined empirically on a case by case basis. However, simulating this with a pairwise lookup table is often impractical. The effective combine mode for the pair is maximum(material0.combineMode, material1.combineMode).

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PhysicsCombineMode.Average
member.summary: Uses the average value of the touching materials: (a+b)/2.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PhysicsCombineMode.Minimum
member.summary: Uses the smaller value of the touching materials: min(a,b).

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PhysicsCombineMode.Multiply
member.summary: Multiplies the values of the touching materials: a*b.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PhysicsCombineMode.Maximum
member.summary: Uses the larger value of the touching materials: max(a, b).

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.RigidbodyConstraints
member.summary: Dynamic rigidbodies movement and rotation locking flags. Provide a mechanism to lock motion along/around a specific axis or set of axes to constrain object motion.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.RigidbodyConstraints.None
member.summary: No constraints.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.RigidbodyConstraints.LockPositionX
member.summary: Freeze motion along the X-axis.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.RigidbodyConstraints.LockPositionY
member.summary: Freeze motion along the Y-axis.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.RigidbodyConstraints.LockPositionZ
member.summary: Freeze motion along the Z-axis.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.RigidbodyConstraints.LockRotationX
member.summary: Freeze rotation along the X-axis.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.RigidbodyConstraints.LockRotationY
member.summary: Freeze rotation along the Y-axis.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.RigidbodyConstraints.LockRotationZ
member.summary: Freeze rotation along the Z-axis.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.RigidbodyConstraints.LockPosition
member.summary: Freeze motion along all axes.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.Assertions.Assert

member.summary: Should an exception be thrown on a failure.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Assertions.Assert.AreApproximatelyEqual(System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Asserts that the values are approximately equal. An absolute error check is used for approximate equality check (|a-b| < tolerance). Default tolerance is 0.00001f. Note: Every time you call the method with tolerance specified, a new instance of Assertions.Comparers.FloatComparer is created. For performance reasons you might want to instance your own comparer and pass it to the AreEqual method. If the tolerance is not specifies, a default comparer is used and the issue does not occur.

member.summary: Get the distance which when added to camera position along the lookat direction will do the effect of zoom to extents (zoom to fit) operation, so all the passed points will fit in the current view. if the returned value is positive, the camera will move toward the lookat direction (ZoomIn). if the returned value is negative, the camera will move in the reverse direction of the lookat direction (ZoomOut).

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.CollisionsHelper.RayIntersectsRay(FlaxEngine.Ray@,FlaxEngine.Ray@,FlaxEngine.Vector3@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the point of intersection, or if there was no intersection.
member.returns: Whether the two objects intersect.
member.remarks: This method performs a ray vs ray intersection test based on the following formula from Goldman. s = det([o_2 - o_1, d_2, d_1 x d_2]) / ||d_1 x d_2||^2 t = det([o_2 - o_1, d_1, d_1 x d_2]) / ||d_1 x d_2||^2 Where o_1 is the position of the first ray, o_2 is the position of the second ray, d_1 is the normalized direction of the first ray, d_2 is the normalized direction of the second ray, det denotes the determinant of a matrix, x denotes the cross product, [ ] denotes a matrix, and || || denotes the length or magnitude of a vector.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.CollisionsHelper.RayIntersectsPlane(FlaxEngine.Ray@,FlaxEngine.Plane@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the distance of the intersection, or 0 if there was no intersection.
member.returns: Whether the two objects intersect.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.CollisionsHelper.RayIntersectsPlane(FlaxEngine.Ray@,FlaxEngine.Plane@,FlaxEngine.Vector3@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the point of intersection, or if there was no intersection.
member.returns: Whether the two objects intersected.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.CollisionsHelper.RayIntersectsTriangle(FlaxEngine.Ray@,FlaxEngine.Vector3@,FlaxEngine.Vector3@,FlaxEngine.Vector3@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a triangle.
member.param: The first vertex of the triangle to test.
The second vertex of the triangle to test.
The third vertex of the triangle to test.
When the method completes, contains the distance of the intersection, or 0 if there was no intersection.
member.returns: Whether the two objects intersected.
member.remarks: This method tests if the ray intersects either the front or back of the triangle. If the ray is parallel to the triangle's plane, no intersection is assumed to have happened. If the intersection of the ray and the triangle is behind the origin of the ray, no intersection is assumed to have happened. In both cases of assumptions, this method returns false.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.FloatR11G11B10
member.summary: Packed vector, layout: R:11 bytes, G:11 bytes, B:10 bytes. The 3D vector is packed into 32 bits as follows: a 5-bit biased exponent and 6-bit mantissa for x component, a 5-bit biased exponent and 6-bit mantissa for y component, a 5-bit biased exponent and a 5-bit mantissa for z. The z component is stored in the most significant bits and the x component in the least significant bits. No sign bits so all partial-precision numbers are positive. (Z10Y11X11): [32] ZZZZZzzz zzzYYYYY yyyyyyXX XXXxxxxx [0]

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.FloatR11G11B10.#ctor(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the structure.
member.param: The floating point value that should be stored in R component (11 bits format).
The floating point value that should be stored in G component (11 bits format).
The floating point value that should be stored in B component (10 bits format).

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the structure.
member.param: The floating point value that should be stored in compressed format.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Int2.DistanceSquared(FlaxEngine.Int2@,FlaxEngine.Int2@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Calculates the squared distance between two vectors.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the squared distance between the two vectors.
member.remarks: Distance squared is the value before taking the square root. Distance squared can often be used in place of distance if relative comparisons are being made. For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Int2.DistanceSquared(FlaxEngine.Int2,FlaxEngine.Int2)
member.summary: Calculates the squared distance between two vectors.
member.returns: The squared distance between the two vectors.
member.remarks: Distance squared is the value before taking the square root. Distance squared can often be used in place of distance if relative comparisons are being made. For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Int3.DistanceSquared(FlaxEngine.Int3@,FlaxEngine.Int3@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Calculates the squared distance between two vectors.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the squared distance between the two vectors.
member.remarks: Distance squared is the value before taking the square root. Distance squared can often be used in place of distance if relative comparisons are being made. For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix.Orthogonalize
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified matrix.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the matrix will be orthogonal to any other given row in the matrix.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting matrix tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.
This operation is performed on the rows of the matrix rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix.Orthonormalize
member.summary: Orthonormalizes the specified matrix.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all rows and columns orthogonal to each other and making all rows and columns of unit length. This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting matrix tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.
This operation is performed on the rows of the matrix rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix.Orthogonalize(FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Matrix@)
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified matrix.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the orthogonalized matrix.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the matrix will be orthogonal to any other given row in the matrix.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting matrix tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.
This operation is performed on the rows of the matrix rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix.Orthogonalize(FlaxEngine.Matrix)
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified matrix.
member.returns: The orthogonalized matrix.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the matrix will be orthogonal to any other given row in the matrix.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting matrix tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.
This operation is performed on the rows of the matrix rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix.Orthonormalize(FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Matrix@)
member.summary: Orthonormalizes the specified matrix.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the orthonormalized matrix.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all rows and columns orthogonal to each other and making all rows and columns of unit length. This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting matrix tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.
This operation is performed on the rows of the matrix rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix.Orthonormalize(FlaxEngine.Matrix)
member.summary: Orthonormalizes the specified matrix.
member.returns: The orthonormalized matrix.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all rows and columns orthogonal to each other and making all rows and columns of unit length. This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting matrix tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.
This operation is performed on the rows of the matrix rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix.UpperTriangularForm(FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Matrix@)
member.summary: Brings the matrix into upper triangular form using elementary row operations.
member.param: The matrix to put into upper triangular form.
When the method completes, contains the upper triangular matrix.
member.remarks: If the matrix is not invertible (i.e. its determinant is zero) than the result of this method may produce Single.Nan and Single.Inf values. When the matrix represents a system of linear equations, than this often means that either no solution exists or an infinite number of solutions exist.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix.ReducedRowEchelonForm(FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Vector4@,FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Vector4@)
member.summary: Brings the matrix into reduced row echelon form using elementary row operations.
member.param: The matrix to put into reduced row echelon form.
The fifth column of the matrix.
When the method completes, contains the resultant matrix after the operation.
When the method completes, contains the resultant fifth column of the matrix.

remarks.para: The fifth column is often called the augmented part of the matrix. This is because the fifth column is really just an extension of the matrix so that there is a place to put all of the non-zero components after the operation is complete.
Often times the resultant matrix will the identity matrix or a matrix similar to the identity matrix. Sometimes, however, that is not possible and numbers other than zero and one may appear.

This method can be used to solve systems of linear equations. Upon completion of this method, the will contain the solution for the system. It is up to the user to analyze both the input and the result to determine if a solution really exists.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.Orthogonalize
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the Matrix3x3 will be orthogonal to any other given row in the Matrix3x3.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.Orthonormalize
member.summary: Orthonormalizes the specified Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all rows and columns orthogonal to each other and making all rows and columns of unit length. This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.summary: Decomposes a Matrix3x3 into an orthonormalized Matrix3x3 q and a right triangular Matrix3x3 r.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the orthonormalized Matrix3x3 of the decomposition.
When the method completes, contains the right triangular Matrix3x3 of the decomposition.

member.param: When the method completes, contains the lower triangular Matrix3x3 of the decomposition.
When the method completes, contains the orthonormalized Matrix3x3 of the decomposition.

When the method completes, contains the rotation component of the decomposed Matrix3x3.
member.remarks: This method is designed to decompose an SRT transformation Matrix3x3 only.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.DecomposeUniformScale(System.Single@,FlaxEngine.Quaternion@)
member.summary: Decomposes a uniform scale matrix into a scale, rotation, and translation. A uniform scale matrix has the same scale in every axis.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the scaling component of the decomposed matrix.
When the method completes, contains the rotation component of the decomposed matrix.
member.remarks: This method is designed to decompose only an SRT transformation matrix that has the same scale in every axis.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.Orthogonalize(FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3@,FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3@)
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified Matrix3x3.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the orthogonalized Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the Matrix3x3 will be orthogonal to any other given row in the Matrix3x3.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.Orthogonalize(FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3)
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified Matrix3x3.
member.returns: The orthogonalized Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the Matrix3x3 will be orthogonal to any other given row in the Matrix3x3.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.Orthonormalize(FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3@,FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3@)
member.summary: Orthonormalizes the specified Matrix3x3.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the orthonormalized Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all rows and columns orthogonal to each other and making all rows and columns of unit length. This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.Orthonormalize(FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3)
member.summary: Orthonormalizes the specified Matrix3x3.
member.returns: The orthonormalized Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all rows and columns orthogonal to each other and making all rows and columns of unit length. This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.UpperTriangularForm(FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3@,FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3@)
member.summary: Brings the Matrix3x3 into upper triangular form using elementary row operations.
member.param: The Matrix3x3 to put into upper triangular form.
When the method completes, contains the upper triangular Matrix3x3.
member.remarks: If the Matrix3x3 is not invertible (i.e. its determinant is zero) than the result of this method may produce Single.Nan and Single.Inf values. When the Matrix3x3 represents a system of linear equations, than this often means that either no solution exists or an infinite number of solutions exist.

member.param: If true, the method will use a fast algorithm which is inapplicable if a scale is applied to the transformation matrix of the OrientedBoundingBox.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Object.Destroy(FlaxEngine.Object,System.Single)
member.summary: Destroys the specified object and clears the reference variable. The object obj will be destroyed now or after the time specified in seconds from now. If obj is a Script it will be removed from the Actor and deleted. If obj is an Actor it will be removed from the Scene and deleted as well as all its Scripts and all children of the Actor. Actual object destruction is always delayed until after the current Update loop, but will always be done before rendering.
member.param: The time left to destroy object (in seconds).

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Object.Destroy``1(``0@,System.Single)
member.summary: Destroys the specified object and clears the reference variable. The object obj will be destroyed now or after the time specified in seconds from now. If obj is a Script it will be removed from the Actor and deleted. If obj is an Actor it will be removed from the Scene and deleted as well as all its Scripts and all children of the Actor. Actual object destruction is always delayed until after the current Update loop, but will always be done before rendering.
member.param: The time left to destroy object (in seconds).

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Object.op_Implicit(FlaxEngine.Object)~System.Boolean
member.summary: Checks if the object exists (reference is not null and the unmanaged object pointer is valid).
member.returns: True if object is valid, otherwise false.

member.summary: Performs a linear interpolation between two quaternions.

When the method completes, contains the linear interpolation of the two quaternions.
member.remarks: This method performs the linear interpolation based on the following formula. start + (end - start) * amount Passing a value of 0 will cause to be returned; a value of 1 will cause to be returned.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector2.DistanceSquared(FlaxEngine.Vector2@,FlaxEngine.Vector2@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Calculates the squared distance between two vectors.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the squared distance between the two vectors.
member.remarks: Distance squared is the value before taking the square root. Distance squared can often be used in place of distance if relative comparisons are being made. For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector2.Orthogonalize(FlaxEngine.Vector2[],FlaxEngine.Vector2[])
member.summary: Orthogonalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthogonalize.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other. This means that any given vector in the list will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector2.Orthonormalize(FlaxEngine.Vector2[],FlaxEngine.Vector2[])
member.summary: Orthonormalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthonormalize.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other and making all vectors of unit length. This means that any given vector will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector2.TransformCoordinate(FlaxEngine.Vector2@,FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Vector2@)
member.summary: Performs a coordinate transformation using the given .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the transformed coordinates.
member.remarks: A coordinate transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is one. The four dimensional vector obtained from the transformation operation has each component in the vector divided by the w component. This forces the w component to be one and therefore makes the vector homogeneous. The homogeneous vector is often preferred when working with coordinates as the w component can safely be ignored.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector2.TransformNormal(FlaxEngine.Vector2@,FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Vector2@)
member.summary: Performs a normal transformation using the given .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the transformed normal.
member.remarks: A normal transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is zero. This causes the fourth row and fourth column of the matrix to be unused. The end result is a vector that is not translated, but all other transformation properties apply. This is often preferred for normal vectors as normals purely represent direction rather than location because normal vectors should not be translated.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector3.DistanceSquared(FlaxEngine.Vector3@,FlaxEngine.Vector3@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Calculates the squared distance between two vectors.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the squared distance between the two vectors.
member.remarks: Distance squared is the value before taking the square root. Distance squared can often be used in place of distance if relative comparisons are being made. For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector3.Orthogonalize(FlaxEngine.Vector3[],FlaxEngine.Vector3[])
member.summary: Orthogonalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthogonalize.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other. This means that any given vector in the list will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector3.Orthonormalize(FlaxEngine.Vector3[],FlaxEngine.Vector3[])
member.summary: Orthonormalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthonormalize.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other and making all vectors of unit length. This means that any given vector will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector3.OrthoNormalize(FlaxEngine.Vector3@,FlaxEngine.Vector3@)
member.summary: Makes vectors normalized and orthogonal to each other

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector3.TransformCoordinate(FlaxEngine.Vector3@,FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Vector3@)
member.summary: Performs a coordinate transformation using the given .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the transformed coordinates.
member.remarks: A coordinate transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is one. The four dimensional vector obtained from the transformation operation has each component in the vector divided by the w component. This forces the w component to be one and therefore makes the vector homogeneous. The homogeneous vector is often preferred when working with coordinates as the w component can safely be ignored.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector3.TransformCoordinate(FlaxEngine.Vector3,FlaxEngine.Matrix)
member.summary: Performs a coordinate transformation using the given .
member.returns: The transformed coordinates.

The four dimensional vector obtained from the transformation operation has each component in the vector divided by the w component. This forces the w component to be one and therefore makes the vector homogeneous. The homogeneous vector is often preferred when working with coordinates as the w component can safely be ignored.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector3.TransformNormal(FlaxEngine.Vector3@,FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Vector3@)
member.summary: Performs a normal transformation using the given .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the transformed normal.
member.remarks: A normal transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is zero. This causes the fourth row and fourth column of the matrix to be unused. The end result is a vector that is not translated, but all other transformation properties apply. This is often preferred for normal vectors as normals purely represent direction rather than location because normal vectors should not be translated.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector4.DistanceSquared(FlaxEngine.Vector4@,FlaxEngine.Vector4@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Calculates the squared distance between two vectors.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the squared distance between the two vectors.
member.remarks: Distance squared is the value before taking the square root. Distance squared can often be used in place of distance if relative comparisons are being made. For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector4.DistanceSquared(FlaxEngine.Vector4,FlaxEngine.Vector4)

member.returns: The squared distance between the two vectors.

For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector4.Orthogonalize(FlaxEngine.Vector4[],FlaxEngine.Vector4[])
member.summary: Orthogonalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthogonalize.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other. This means that any given vector in the list will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Vector4.Orthonormalize(FlaxEngine.Vector4[],FlaxEngine.Vector4[])
member.summary: Orthonormalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthonormalize.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other and making all vectors of unit length. This means that any given vector will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .
